title: Blockchair
subtitle: Blockchain Explorer
description: Block explorer and the most powerful API for BTC, ETH, XRP, XLM, BCH, LTC, DASH, BSV, DOGE, GRS and TON that allow you to find, sort and filter transactions and addresses.

homepage.title: Blockchair ‚Äî Universal blockchain explorer and search engine

screen1.description: Blockchair is the most private search engine for {blockchains}.

scope.tooltip: Click to paste a random example into the search box

screen2.description: Dive into blockchain data analysis applying filters and sorting. Create and extract your own datasets. Database dumps are also available.

examples.description: Try out examples of what you can find on Blockchair:

screen3.description: Great tools to work with crypto data: request Blockchair API to get blockchain data, explore trends and correlations looking at Charts, analyze market trends with Markets & Portfolio, broadcast transactions, download dumps with historical data and so much more.

api.title: Professional API
api.description: Access blockchain data with Blockchair API

charts.title: Charts
charts.chart_name: Bitcoin price over the last 3 months
charts.description: Get an overview of latest data trends by looking at over 120 charts

markets.title: Markets & Portfolio
markets.description: Click to see top 1000 cryptoassets and start building your portfolio

ethereum.title: Unconfirmed
ethereum.hint: We're waiting for 6 blocks until blocks and transactions get into our main database. We also don't process neither calls nor uncles for unconfirmed blocks.

permalink.caption: Permalink
permalink.tooltip: A permalink saves sorting, conditions, and the list of shown columns. Unless there are time conditions, the data can change. If you don't need to save the list of shown columns, you can just copy the URL from the address bar.

privacy-o-meter.title: Privacy-o-meter

heuristic_names.discrepancy_script_types_and_round_value: Discrepancy between Script types and Round value
heuristic_names.discrepancy_script_types_and_recipient_b: Discrepancy between Script types and Recipient by value
heuristic_names.discrepancy_round_value_and_recipient_by: Discrepancy between Round value and Recipient by value
heuristic_names.discrepancy_no_output_of_the_same_type_a: Discrepancy: no output of the same type as inputs

heuristic_descriptions.inputs: Unless it's a CoinJoin transaction it's safe to assume that all input addresses belong to one person
heuristic_descriptions.script_types: If all inputs has the same type, and exactly one of the outputs is not of the same type ‚Äî this output can be considered as the recipient
heuristic_descriptions.p2sh_types: If all inputs are m of n multisig P2SH, and all outputs are multisig P2SH, but exactly one of the outputs has another m of n structure ‚Äî this output can be considered as the recipient
heuristic_descriptions.p2wsh_types: If all inputs are m of n multisig P2WSH, and all outputs are multisig P2WSH, but exactly one of the outputs has another m of n structure ‚Äî this output can be considered as the recipient
heuristic_descriptions.round_value: If one of the outputs has a round value (like exactly 1 BTC) ‚Äî this output can be considered as the recipient
heuristic_descriptions.recipient_by_value: If the recipient is the smaller output, there's no point in having some of the inputs
heuristic_descriptions.t1-2_bigger_value_25: One of the two outputs is 25 times bigger than the other meaning that it's potentially the change output
heuristic_descriptions.t1-2_bigger_value_100: One of the two outputs is 100 times bigger than the other meaning that it's potentially the change output
heuristic_descriptions.t1-2_bigger_value_250: One of the two outputs is 250 times bigger than the other meaning that it's potentially the change output
heuristic_descriptions.t1-2_bigger_value_1000: One of the two outputs is 1000 times bigger than the other meaning that it's potentially the change output
heuristic_descriptions.coinbase_known: The recipient is the known miner
heuristic_descriptions.coinbase_unknown: The recipient is an unknown miner
heuristic_descriptions.coinjoin: This is a CoinJoin transaction. This cancels all other heuristics.
heuristic_descriptions.round_fee: The transaction has a round fee amount, the sender is probably using some specific software
heuristic_descriptions.asc_output_values: For transaction with more than 5 outputs ‚Äî they are ordered by value ascending ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.desc_output_values: For transaction with more than 5 outputs ‚Äî they are ordered by value descending ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.asc_output_addresses: For transaction with more than 5 outputs ‚Äî they are ordered by addresses in alphabetical order ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.desc_output_addresses: For transaction with more than 5 outputs ‚Äî they are ordered by addresses in alphabetical order ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.asc_input_values: For transaction with more than 5 inputs ‚Äî they are ordered by value ascending ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.desc_input_values: For transaction with more than 5 inputs ‚Äî they are ordered by value descending ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.asc_input_addresses: For transaction with more than 5 inputs ‚Äî they are ordered by addresses in alphabetical order ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.desc_input_addresses: For transaction with more than 5 inputs ‚Äî they are ordered by addresses in alphabetical order ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.asc_input_timestamps: For transaction with more than 5 inputs ‚Äî they are ordered by age ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.desc_input_timestamps: For transaction with more than 5 inputs ‚Äî they are ordered by age ‚Äî that may due to some specific software usage
heuristic_descriptions.asc_output_values_except_first: All outputs are sorted by value ascending except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change address.
heuristic_descriptions.asc_output_values_except_last: All outputs are sorted by value ascending except for the last one, that may mean that the first output is the change address.
heuristic_descriptions.asc_output_addresses_except_first: All outputs are sorted by addresses in alphabetical order except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change address.
heuristic_descriptions.asc_output_addresses_except_last: All outputs are sorted by addresses in alphabetical order except for the last one, that may mean that the first output is the change address.
heuristic_descriptions.desc_output_values_except_first:
All outputs are sorted by value descending except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change address
All outputs are sorted by value descending except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change addressAll outputs are sorted by value descending except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change address
heuristic_descriptions.desc_output_values_except_last: All outputs are sorted by value descending except for the last one, that may mean that the last output is the change address
heuristic_descriptions.desc_output_addresses_except_last: All outputs are sorted by address alphabetically descending except for the last one, that may mean that the last output is the change address
heuristic_descriptions.desc_output_addresses_except_first: All outputs are sorted by address alphabetically descending except for the first one, that may mean that the first output is the change address
heuristic_descriptions.simple_reuse_1-2: The sender uses the same address for receiving and for change
heuristic_descriptions.simple_reuse_N-2: The sender uses the same address for receiving and for change
heuristic_descriptions.simple_reuse_1-N: The sender (probably an exchange) uses the same address for receiving and for change
heuristic_descriptions.simple_reuse_same_address_in_inputs: There's multiple occurences of the same address in inputs
heuristic_descriptions.sweep_1-1: The sender uses the 'send everything' option to either pay someone (e.g. an exchange) or just moving the funds to another wallet (1 input)
heuristic_descriptions.sweep_1-1_to_another_type: The sender uses the "send everything" option to either pay someone or move the funds to a new wallet type (1 input)
heuristic_descriptions.sweep_N-1: The sender uses the "send everything" option to either pay someone (e.g. an exchange) or just moving the funds to another wallet
heuristic_descriptions.sweep_N-1_to_another_type: The sender uses the "send everything" option to either pay someone (e.g. an exchange) or just moving the funds to another wallet of another type than the initial addresses
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_unnecessary_inputs: The smaller input is unnecessary, as whichever of the outputs is the recipient, there's no need to include that input
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_various_input_types: The inputs are of different types. That means the sender is probably using the software allowing to create the same address type for the change as the recipient has, trying to circumvent the script_types heuristic
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_script_types_and_round_value: script_types and round_value heuristics yield different results
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_script_types_and_recipient_b: script_types and recipient by value heuristics yield different results
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_round_value_and_recipient_by: round_value and recipient by value heuristics yield different results
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_p2sh_various_input_types: The P2SH input types are different (e.g. one is 2-of-2 multisig, and the other is 2-of-3)
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_p2wsh_various_input_types: The P2WSH input types are different (e.g. one is 2-of-2 multisig, and the other is 2-of-3)
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_same_address_in_outputs: There are outputs with the same address ‚Äî that makes no economical sense
heuristic_descriptions.discrepancy_no_output_of_the_same_type_a: Probably the sender uses software generating the same change address type as the recipient address has
heuristic_descriptions.rare_fingerprint: This transaction has quite unique technical characteristics

transaction_types.N1: Transaction with just 1 output (either a sweep to another address by the same owner, or a transfer using a "send everything I have" option)
transaction_types.N2: Transaction with 2 outputs ‚Äî most common in wallets ‚Äî where one of the outputs is the recipient, and the other one is the change address
transaction_types.NN: Transaction with more than 2 outputs ‚Äî most common in exchanges and services that use payout batching

privacy-o-meter.highlight_clusterized: Highlight sender addresses (including change), and recipient address
privacy-o-meter.is_finalized_description: Shows whether the transaction has the final score (all outputs are spent)
privacy-o-meter.clusterized_description: Addresses potentially belonging to one entity based on the applicable heuristics

info.title: What is this?
info.text:
While Bitcoin is considered to be a privacy-oriented system, the blockchain is open to be analyzed by anyone.

Privacy-o-meter by Blockchair shows whether your transaction is susceptible to some of the heuristics used by numerous transaction tracing tools.

The higher the score ‚Äî the higher the chance they won‚Äôt be able to extract anything useful. A low score means it‚Äôs probably too easy to, for example, distinguish the change address from the recipient‚Äôs address.

whitepaper.description: Check Satoshi Nakamoto's whitepaper for consistency by hash on different websites and from Bitcoin outputs

what_is.caption: What is this page?
what_is.description1: This page shows whether different Bitcoin sites serve the original Bitcoin whitepaper or an edited version of it. Once an hour we calculate SHA-256 hashes of the files and compare them with the hash of the original whitepaper (that would be b1674191a88ec5cdd733e4240a81803105dc412d6c6708d53ab94fc248f4f553).
what_is.description2: There have been some suggestions to alter the whitepaper hosted on bitcoin.org (e.g. {github_issue_link} is still open). We believe that editing an academic paper and rewriting the Bitcoin history in order to accommodate someone's business interests is downright unacceptable.

where_find.caption: Where can I find the whitepaper in the Bitcoin blockchain?
where_find.description1: First of all, there are some null-data outputs containing the hash as plaintext. You can find them {outputs_table_link}. Examples: {transaction1_link}, {transaction2_link}, {transaction3_link}
where_find.outputs_table: using a filter on the outputs table
where_find.description2: Also there are null-data outputs which contain the hash as hex. The current version of our search engine doesn't yet have support for filtering scripts by hex values, but since the hex value can be represented as binary text, we can {outputs_table_search_link} of this text. Examples: {transaction1_link}, {transaction2_link}, {transaction3_link}
where_find.description3: More importantly, there's transaction {transaction_link} which contains the pdf file itself. Here's {bitcoin_stackexchange_link}. It may be possible to edit the whitepaper on some websites, but it's not possible to alter the blockchain.
where_find.bitcoin_stackexchange: an instruction on how to parse it

what_is.caption: What is Blockchair?
what_is.description1: {service} is a blockchain search and analytics engine for {blockchains_links} or you can also say it's an engine that consists of blockchain explorers on steroids. You can filter and sort blocks, transactions, and their content by a variety of different criteria, as well as perform full-text search over the blockchains.
what_is.description2: To understand what our search engine is capable of you can try to search for {search_bitcoin_link}, look at {biggest_bitcoin_cash_blocks_link}, or try any of other examples featured on {homepage_link}.
what_is.description3: We aim to become Google for blockchains. Our next priority is to bring the ability to search over more other decentralized projects like IPFS and SWARM. In addition, we provide researchers with a way to batch export data from blockchains.
